I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  During the 2003 Country Programming Mission of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) confirmed its request for technical 
assistance (TA) to prepare an integrated roads development project (the Project) in Hunan 
Province. ADB’s Fact-Finding Mission visited the project area in March 2004, carried out rapid 
environmental assessment and an initial poverty and social assessment (IPSA), and collected 
necessary  information.  This  paper  is  based  on  the  understandings  reached  with  the 
Government on the objectives, scope, costs, consultants’ term of reference, and implementation 
arrangements for the TA, and the Mission’s observations in the field. The preliminary is included 
in ADB’s 2004 program for the PRC,1 and the proposed loan is included in the 2005 program. 
The project framework is attached in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The  PRC’s  economic  growth  since  the  1980s  has  resulted  in  an  unprecedented 
expansion in intra- and inte-rprovincial traffic. The economy’s changing structure and increasing 
diversification have altered the pattern of transport demand. The demand for road transport has 
outpaced  that  of  other  transport  modes.  Movement  of  goods  and  passengers  by  road  is 
increasing rapidly, and is more flexible and responsive than other modes to the needs of a 
market economy. The shift in transport demand also reflects the loosening of anticompetitive 
restrictions in the road transport industry. Between 1990 and 2003, road traffic grew around 
9.6% per annum for passenger traffic, reaching 769.6 billion passenger-kilometers (km); and 
around 5.7% per annum for freight, reaching 708 billion ton-km. In 2003, road traffic accounted 
for 55.7% of the country’s total passenger traffic and 13.2% of total freight traffic. With the 
country’s rapid economic growth, low vehicle ownership rates, lower car prices after World 
Trade Organization accession, increasing access to loans to finance automobile purchases, and 
investment in automotive manufacturing ($6 billion were provided by the state banks during 
2001–2003), the fast expansion in vehicle fleets will continue in the coming years. ADB supports 
the improvement of road transport efficiency and service quality through its TA program.2  
 
3.  Despite the huge investment, the road network is still underdeveloped in both quality and 
extent, and does not provide access to large parts of the country, particularly in the poorer 
inland regions. High-standard roads (above class II)3 account for only 12% of the total network. 
The remaining 88% are medium- to low-grade paved roads and gravel roads. The road density is 
low,  with  only  1,100  km  of  roads  for  every  1  million  inhabitants,  although  the  density  has 
increased from 12.1 km per 100 square kilometer (km2) in 1995 to 18.6 km per 100 km2 in 2003. 
The growing road transport demand has put a strain on the road infrastructure, as manifested 
by the congestion and bottlenecks in the network. Weaknesses in the road network have 
resulted in high transport and logistics cost between interior provinces and the coastal ports.4 
 
4.  Transport conditions for the rural poor are not adequate in the PRC. Many of the rural 
poor in the country reside in partial or full isolation, which bloats their transportation costs and 
thus restricts their access to basic goods and services. This limitation keeps the poor from

reliable transport to input and output markets stimulates higher production in cash-crop farming, 
thereby speeding up the transition from subsistence farming to a market economy. Upgraded 
rural transport also increases the nonfarm income opportunities of the rural poor. Linking the 
depressed rural areas to the economic centers will make education and health facilities more 
easily available to them. 
 
5.  To meet the growing demand for improved access to markets and services, and to build 
a conducive environment to the private sector, the Government has made major efforts to 
increase the country’s road capacity. The heart of the road network development strategy is the 
National Trunk Highway System (NTHS), a 35,000 km system of interprovincial expressways 
and high-class highways to be constructed over 20 years (target completion: 2007). The NTHS 
will be complemented by the development of a network of national, provincial, county, and 
township roads. The Government’s road development policies are: (i) constructing expressways 
to  expand  the  NTHS  and  link  all  cities  that  have  a  population  more  than  500,000;  and  
(ii) developing secondary roads, particularly those that will help reduce poverty and promote 
rural markets. The Government adopted the Western Region Development Strategy, a key 
theme of the 10th Five-Year Plan (2001–2005), to enhance economic development in the 
western part of the country, where most of the poor reside. The strategy aims to reduce the 
disparity between the western and coastal regions, and assigns a high priority to road sector 
development as a means to promote economic growth and poverty reduction in the western 
region. To implement the Government’s policies, the National Rural Road Development Plan 
has been drafted. The plan aims to link all county centers with high-class highways (above class 
II), to provide all township centers with paved road access, and to ensure that all administrative 
villages have all-weather road access.5 Hunan Province also formulated its own 10 year road 
development plan (2001–2010), extending networks of local (county and township) roads and 
enhancing road connections among regions and provinces. 
 
6.  Hunan, in the central-western part of the PRC and in the middle reaches of the Yangtze 
River, is bordered by Jiangxi to the east, Chongqing and Guizhou to the west, Guangdong and 
Guangxi to the south, and Hubei to the north. In 2003, the region’s per capita gross domestic 
product  was  CNY6,549,  85%  of  the  national  average.  Agriculture  is  the  mainstay  of  the 
economy, employing 69% of the labor force. The major agricultural products—ramie, wheat, 
rice, corn, tea, citrus fruits, and soybeans⎯are grown in the Yuan Valley, through which the 
Project passes. Hunan has a potential for industrial development. Its industrial output grew over 
20% per annum during 2000–2003. The leading industrial sectors include steel, nonferrous 
metals, coal, oil and chemical processing, machinery, and textiles. The demand for Hunan's 
products from other provinces has increased sharply in recent years. However, weaknesses in 
road infrastructure development lag, failing to adequately support economic growth. About 86% 
of the roads in Hunan are below class III. The national highway (NR319), which runs parallel to 
the proposed expressway and currently serves as a link to major trading destinations such as 
Chongqing, is a combination of class III and lower roads. The pavement is in poor condition. 
Two thirds of the road is frequently congested and nonmotorized traffic interferes with fast 
moving traffic. These two factors contribute to frequent accidents and poor safety. Traffic on 
NR319 has grown at around 7.3% per annum in the past few years and will exceed its capacity 
at several points by 2008. 
 
                                                 
5  Rural roads will be developed in three stages. By 2005, the total extent of rural roads will be 1.6 million km; by 
2010, 1.85 million km, connecting 100% townships and administrative villages in the PRC; and by 2020, 2.5 million 
km and transport services will be provided to administrative village level.

3
7.  The expressway from Jishou to Chadong proposed under the Project will constitute a 
75.3 km section of the Changsha-Chongqing western corridor, one of the eight priority western 
corridors included in the 10th Five-Year Plan.6 With this proposed expressway, the journey time 
from Jishou to Chadong will be reduced by 2 hours. The Project is in the western part of Hunan, 
passing through the Xiangxi Autonomous Prefecture of Tujia and Miao Nationalities⎯one of the 
well-known poverty areas in the PRC. The project area includes Jishou City and two counties in 
Xiangxi Prefecture: Baojin and Huayuan.7 The project area is largely rural and mountainous with 
limited accessibility. The project area has a total population of 833,000, of which 74% is rural. In 
2002, per capita rural income was CNY1,267 for Baojin County, CNY1,181 for Huayuan County, 
and  CNY1,881  for  Jishou  City.  The  proportion  of  rural  population  is  86%  in  Baojin,  85% 
Huayuan, and 53% Jishou. The Project will open the region by linking the west to the east, and 
promoting economic development. It will also improve the quality of life for local people, with 
better access to social services, including reduced transport costs and travel time to seek health 
care. The project area has 431 health clinics and 555 primary schools. 
 
8.  ADB and the Government have had extensive discussions on how to maximize the 
poverty reduction impact of road investments. The location of ADB-financed road sector projects 
has shifted from the northeast and coastal areas to the poorer central, northwest and southwest 
regions. To strengthen the impacts on poverty reduction, since 1995 the scope of the ADB-
financed  road  projects  has  been  broadened  to  include  improvements  to  local  roads,  thus 
providing better access to poor counties and townships.8 In line with ADB’s policy dialogue, a 
local road improvement program will be integrated into the Project. The proposed TA will 
determine  the  scope  of  the  local  road  improvement  component  that  will  complement  the 
expressway. The integrated approach will help spread the expressway benefits to the poor.  
Better tie-ins between the expressway and local roads will help rural agricultural products reach 
markets and allow farmers to upgrade farming practices. 
 
9.  ADB’s operating strategy in the PRC’s road sector supports (i) constructing roads that 
connect major growth centers with hinterland economies; (ii) integrating the network, so that the 
NTHS is supported by a system of local roads, particularly those that provide access to poor 
areas; (iii) enhancing the provision of transport services to the poor; (iv) promoting road safety 
and  reducing  vehicle  emissions;  (v)  institutional  strengthening  to  increase  the  commercial 
orientation and managerial efficiency in expressway operations; (vi) adopting appropriate pricing 
policies to ensure the optimization of road transport capacity; and (vii) using alternative methods 
of investment financing, including private sector participation.  
 
10.   The project preparatory work is well advanced. The feasibility study for the Project was 
submitted  to  National  Development  and  Reform  Commission  in  December  2003  and  its 
approval is expected by October 2004. The preliminary design is expected to complete by  
30 November 2004. Within 6 months of the completion of the preliminary design, the detailed 
design  will  complete.  An  environmental  impact  assessment  (EIA)  will  be  completed  by  
30 November 2004. Preparation of the resettlement plan will start in October 2004 and be 
completed by 31 December 2004. The IPSA and rapid environmental assessment carried out

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
11.  The TA will help the Government prepare an integrated roads development project to 
support pro-poor economic growth and reduce poverty in the project area.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
12.  The  TA  will  assist  the  Hunan  Provincial  Communications  Department  (HPCD)  to  
(i) refine the feasibility study, including the EIA and summary EIA, resettlement plan, and 
poverty  impact  analysis  for  the  proposed  Project,  in  conformity  with  ADB’s  requirements;  
(ii) review the project design and scope to make the Project more pro-poor, including the need 
to integrate a local roads and feeder roads component into the Project; (iii) identify important 
socioeconomic indicators and the monitoring mechanisms; (iv) confirm the technical, economic, 
and financial viability of the proposed investments; (v) review and update transport and road 
profiles; (vi) review the externally financed road projects to improve the efficiency of expressway 
operations; and (vii) discuss the major policy issues, assess the poverty impact of the Project, 
and propose measures for maximizing the positive impacts on the poor population in the project 
area.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $625,000 equivalent, comprising $363,000 of 
foreign  exchange  cost  and  $262,000  equivalent  of  local  currency  cost.  ADB  will  provide 
$500,000  equivalent  to  cover  the  entire  foreign  exchange  cost  and  a  portion  of  the  local 
currency cost amounting to $137,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB's TA funding program. HPCD will finance the remaining $125,000 equivalent to cover the 
costs of office accommodation and support services, local communications, local transport, 
office supplies, and other facilities and services required for the implementation of the TA.  
The detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 3. The Government has been advised that approval 
of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  A team of international consultants in association with domestic consulting firm(s) will be 
engaged using the simplified technical proposal procedures based on the quality- and cost-
based selection method and in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the selection and engagement of domestic 
consultants. The TA will require a total of 28 person-months of consulting services, including  
13 person-months of international and 15 person-months of domestic consultancy, to carry out 
the  study,  as  defined  in  the  outline  terms  of  reference  (Appendix  4).  The  international 
consultants will provide expertise in (i) highway and structural engineering, including traffic 
forecast  analysis;  (ii)  tunnel  engineering;  (iii)  transport  economics;  (iv)  financial  analysis, 
expressway management, and private sector participation in expressways; (v) resettlement 
planning;  (vi)  poverty  and  socioeconomic  analysis;  and  (vii)  environmental  aspects.  
The  domestic  consultants  will  have  expertise  in  (i)  highway  and  structure  engineering,

5
(ii)  transport  economics  and  financial  analysis,  (iii)  socioeconomic  and  resettlement,  and  
(iv) environment engineering.  
 
15.  The Government and ADB agree to include this TA as one of the projects under the Pilot 
Study for Delegation of Consultant Recruitment and Supervision under Technical Assistance to 
Executing Agencies (Pilot Study)9 approved by ADB. In particular, the Government agrees to 
follow  the  implementation  procedures  outlined  in  the  pilot  study  and  such  other  detailed 
procedures and practices as the ADB may require from time to time. The Government has 
acknowledged that the terms and conditions of the Technical Assistance Framework Agreement 
(TAFA) executed between the Government and ADB apply to this TA. Pursuant to Section 3.01 
of the TAFA, ADB has agreed to delegate consultant selection and supervision for firms under 
this TA to the Government. The TA letter agreement to be issued under the TAFA for this TA 
will accordingly reflect this arrangement. 
 
16.  HPCD will be the Executing Agency for the TA and will be responsible for supervision 
and monitoring of TA activities, including consultant recruitment and supervision, and liaison 
with government agencies and organizations. HPCD will also provide office accommodation and 
transport  arrangement.  The  TA  will  start  in  November  2004,  when  the  consultants  are 
scheduled to be fielded. The consulting services will be carried out over a 5 month period, with 
the TA due to be completed by April 2005. HPCD will provide ADB and the consultants with the 
feasibility study; engineering studies; EIA; resettlement plan; and any other materials, recent 
studies, and reports required for the implementation of the TA. The consultants will maintain 
close relationships with the Government and HPCD, and inform them of progress and findings. 
Tripartite meetings involving the Government, ADB staff, and the consultants will be held in the 
PRC to provide advice and guidance to the consultants and review their reports. Equipment to 
be provided for the consultants under the TA will be procured by the consultants in accordance 
with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. 
 
17.  The consultants will submit to HPCD, with copies to ADB, the following reports: (i) an 
inception report, including a survey implementation plan with a proposed questionnaire for 
socioeconomic, resettlement, and poverty reduction impacts, 2 weeks after commencement of 
services; (ii) an interim report, 8 weeks after the commencement of services, which will indicate 
the situation of ethnic minorities and confirm the need for an ethnic minorities development plan 
(EMDP)  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Indigenous  Peoples’  Policy,  and  indicate  an  initial 
assessment in the areas of economic, financial and poverty analysis; (iii) a draft final report, 
draft EIA and summary EIA, draft resettlement plan, draft EMDP, and draft social and poverty 
assessment  report,  14  weeks  after  the  commencement;  and  (vi)  the  final  report,  EIA  and 
summary EIA, resettlement plan, social and poverty assessment report, and EMDP, 2 weeks 
after receiving comments from ADB, the Government, and HPCD. ADB requires five copies of 
each report in the English language. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for preparing the Hunan Roads Development 
III Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

What type of poverty analysis is needed? 
The Xiangxi Autonomous Prefecture, where the Project is located, is a well-known poverty areas in the PRC, 
and one of three prioritized minority prefectures under the Government’s Western Region Development 
Strategy. Poverty analysis can be confined to Baojin, Huayuan, and Jishou,. With a total population of 833,000

population, 74% is rural. Average per capita rural income is CNY1,267 for Baojin, CNY1,182 for Huayuan, and 
CNY1,881 for Jishou.  About 27% of the rural population is poor (earning less than CNY900).
